name: p-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.

name: p-bromotoluene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The benzene ring is the base structure, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. A p-substituted toluene generally has a higher melting point than benzene itself due to added steric hindrance and molecular weight, which contribute to its increase. A methyl group (toluene) adds approximately +20°C. The addition of a bromine atom, which is quite large and heavy, will further increase the melting point due to increased intermolecular London dispersion forces. The effect of a bromine atom generally contributes +30°C to the melting point.
